Reaction conditions: 300 °C, 2.0 MPa, H2/CO = 1.0, 36 L•h−1•g−1 g Catalyst preparation: Fe-MIL-88B precursors were carbonized at 700 °C for 4 h; Reduction conditions: 400 °C, pure CO, 4h; Reaction conditions: 300 °C, 2.0 MPa, H2/CO = 1.0, 36 L•h−1•g−1 h Reaction conditions: 280 °C, 1.5 MPa, H2/CO = 2.0, 2 L•h−1•g−1, and TOS of ca. 200 h Highly active FexOy@SiO2 catalyst for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis through the confinement effect of metal organic frameworks material: Preparation and structure-activity relationship Xiangning Jiang Yao Chen Mehar U Nisa Xin Li Ning Zhao Zhenhua Li ⁎ Key Lab for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering (Tianjin), Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China Key Lab for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering (Tianjin) Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Key Lab for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering (Tianjin), Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Metal Organic Frameworks makes it being used as a template to prepare highly dispersed catalysts. The Fe@C catalyst prepared by pyrolysis of Fe-MOF precursor, depicts a core-shell structure with carbon layers being coated on the outer surface of iron species. Since the diffusion of molecules through carbon layers is suppressed, the active iron sites in the interior could not be fully utilized. Based on this realization, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the silicon source was introduced the MOF during the preparation process of Fe-MOF. After carbonization and calcination, the carbon layer was removed while the iron species were confined by the SiO2 yielding the FexOy@SiO2 catalyst. The confinement effect of SiO2 greatly prevented the agglomeration of iron species during calcination process. Compared with Fe@C catalyst without silicon source, the prepared FexOy@SiO2 catalyst resulted in an enhanced FTS activity with FTY as 4.54 × 10−4 molCO/(gFe⋅s) and gasoline fraction selectivity. Upon using same quantity of TEOS, the dispersion degree of iron species and the confinement effect of SiO2 could be regulated by just changing the introduction order of TEOS, corresponding different FTS performances. The FexOy-SiO2 interaction in the catalyst and its influence on the properties of the FexOy@SiO2 catalyst are discussed and structure-activity relationship was explored. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal organic frameworks Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Tetraethyl orthosilicate Metal-support interaction 1 Introduction Fossil resources are one of the main source of energy. The use of fossil resources in the 21st century has caused serious environmental problems. In particular, the NOx and SOx produced during the combustion process produces acid rain which is harmful for soil and water sources. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis is one of the most feasible methods for converting syngas (a mixture of CO and H2) into liquid fuels and bulk chemicals which do not contain sulfur and nitrogen and thus are environmentally friendly [1–6]. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis mainly uses cobalt, iron, and ruthenium as the active phases. According to literature findings, among cobalt, iron, and ruthenium, iron-based catalysts have certain advantages, including the following: (i) They are cheap, widely available, and more suitable for industrialization. (ii) They have stronger activity for Water-gas shift (WGS) reactions under FTS conditions, which can adjust the H2/CO molar ratio in situ to convert syngas emitted from coal or biomass. (iii) The iron-based catalyst has a relatively high activation temperature, and its product selectivity is more biased towards short-chain unsaturated hydrocarbons, short-chain oxygenates and gasoline fractions, which are among the most important bulk chemicals [7,8]. To improve the performance of iron-based catalysts, a support is often added to iron-based catalysts to inhibit the agglomeration of the active phase and improve the reaction performance of the catalyst [9–11]. The oxides including SiO2, ZnO, TiO2, and γ-Al2O3 are widely used supports but the main disadvantage is the formation of mixed oxides that are extremely difficult to be reduced and then inactive to FTS [12,13]. In addition, it is hard to achieve not only high loading but also high dispersion on traditional oxide supports, which also limits the FTS performance of catalysts [8]. In recent years, MOF materials with metal particles and organic ligands have been used as a scalable hybrid porous material [14]. MOF can be converted into porous metal nanoparticle/carbon heterostructures by hydrolysis or pyrolysis, which made it receiving extensive attention and applications in supercapacitors, heavy metal removal, rechargeable batteries, and catalysis [15]. Using Fe-MOF as the precursor, an iron-based catalyst was prepared by high-temperature pyrolysis in an inert atmosphere for FTS reaction [16]. It was reported that the catalyst has not only high iron loading but also high iron species dispersion. The highly dispersed iron nanoparticles are embedded in the microporous carbon matrix that weakens the metal-support interaction and promotes reduction and carbonization of iron oxides. However, the catalysts do not show the potential superior FTS reaction performance. Qiu et al. [17] prepared Co@C-550 and Co@NC-550 catalysts by pyrolyzing ZIF-67 and Co-MOF-74. These catalysts have a small crystalline size of cobalt species (6 ∼ 8 nm) at cobalt loading as high as 30 ∼ 53 wt.% but achieved low CO conversion within 10% ∼ 30%. Chen et al. [18] used CTAB as a surfactant to prepare ZIF-67 with different particle sizes. The catalyst nCTAB-Co@C from direct pyrolysis of ZIF-67 showed CO conversion of 30.7% ∼ 40.1%. Nisa et al. [19] prepared the Fe-based catalysts by pyrolysis of Fe-MIL-88B. The catalysts were activated in different reducing atmospheres, resulting in as low CO conversion as 5.15% ∼ 14.05%. They deduced that the carbon layer enclosed on the metal surface may reduce the availability of the active sites and then affect the adsorption behavior of CO and H2, thus reducing the FTS activity of the catalyst. Some Fe-MOF-SiO2 systems were reported. Sun et al [20] prepared MOF derived core-SiO2 shell nanomaterial Fe-MOF-74@SiO2 by a facile hydrothermal method that was applied to activate persulfate (PS) for dimethyl phthalate (DMP) degradation. They found that the SiO2-coated catalyst was more stable and exhibited higher DMP degradation efficiency. The existence of SiO2 plays an important role in stabilizing the Fe species from MOF material, which makes it having better performance. Zhao et al [21] used nanoscale silica-coated iron and MOF-5 to prepare a magnetic nanomaterial Fe@MOF-5 by co-precipitation. The nanomaterial Fe@MOF-5 shows superior performance for magnetic solid phase extraction for five kinds of N- and S-containing polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. In addition, a Co-based FTS catalyst with not only high cobalt loading but also high dispersion was obtained by introducing a silicon source to ZIF-67 was reported and showed excellent FTS performance [22]. Aspired by these applications, we tried to prepare the Fe-MOF-SiO2 catalyst derived from Fe-containing MOF materials and investigate its performance in FTS. In this paper, TEOS as a silicon source was introduced into the preparation process of Fe-MIL-88B. With the confinement effect of the regular pore structure of Fe-MIL-88B, TEOS could be uniformly anchored into the pore structure and hydrolyzed to intermediate that was transformed to SiO2 after calcination. The adding stage of TEOS during Fe-MIL-88B preparation may affect the filtration speed of TEOS, physical and chemical structures of iron species, SiO2 distribution and the metal-support interaction, which will exert an influence on FTS performance. Therefore, we prepared three FexOy@SiO2-x catalysts by tuning the adding stage of TEOS during Fe-MIL-88B preparation process. The morphological structure, metal-support interaction, chemical/physical properties of the catalyst are studied, and the structure-activity relationship is explored based on characterization results. 2 Experiment 2.1 Chemicals Iron chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3⋅6H2O AR), N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, AR), and p-phthalic acid (BDC, AR) was purchased from Aladdin Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). TEOS (tetraethyl orthosilicate, AR) was purchased from Macklin Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China), while NaOH (Sodium hydroxide, AR) was purchased from Kermel Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). All the chemicals were used as received without any further purification processing. 2.2 Preparation of Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2 precursor The preparation procedure for Fe-MIL-88B precursor is as follows: 50 mL of DMF and 4 mL of 2 M NaOH were fast mixed to form solution A. Then 2.70 g of FeCl3⋅6H2O and 1.16 g of BDC were added to the above solution A, which was stirred continuously for 2 h (900 rpm) and then transferred into a Teflon pot at 100 °C for 12 h. After centrifugal washing (8500 rpm, 5 min) with deionized water and ethanol for 3 times, the solid phase precipitate was collected. After drying in vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h. The obtained orange powder was named as Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-0. In the preparation process, all reagents are added instantly without controlling adding rate. During the above preparation procedure of Fe-MIL-88B, 0.005 mol of TEOS was added in different stages, while the other preparation conditions were same as the preparation of Fe-MIL-88B. The following is the details for preparing Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-x precursor, which was illustrated by Fig. 1 . FeCl3⋅6H2O and TEOS were added to the mixture solution, which dissolved DMF and NaOH, then stirring the mixture for 1 h. Before crystallization, BDC was added with continuously stirring for 1 h. The obtained product was named as Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-1. FeCl3⋅6H2O, TEOS and BDC were added to the mixture solution, which dissolved DMF and NaOH. After stirring for 2 h, the mixture was crystallized. The obtained product was named as Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-2. FeCl3⋅6H2O and BDC were added to the mixture solution, which dissolved DMF and NaOH. After stirring the mixture for 1 h, the TEOS was added with continuously stirring for 1 h. The obtained product was named as Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-3. 2.3 Preparation of catalysts The obtained Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-x precursors were carbonized in a tube oven at 600 °C (heating rate 3 °C/min) for 120 min in an Ar flow rate of 120 mL/min and then reduced to room temperature, getting the sample that was labeled as Fe@C@SiO2-x (x=0, 1, 2, 3). The obtained black powders were calcinated in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 1 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min, getting the catalyst that was labeled as FexOy@xSiO2-x (x=0, 1, 2, 3). The obtained FexOy@SiO2-x catalysts were used for reduction and FTS reaction test. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The crystalline structures of the samples were characterized using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Smartlab 9kW) with Cu-Kα as radiation source. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM), HRTEM, HAADF-STEM and EDX-mapping were characterized by JEM F200, which was fabricated by the JEOL company. The TEM images were taken at the work voltage 200 kV. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and EDX-mapping images were taken on a Hitachi Regulus 8100. And the platinum plating process was conducted to enhance the electroconductibility. Then the SEM images were taken at the work voltage 3 kV. The textural properties of samples were measured by a N2 adsorption/desorption method on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. 0.2 g sample was pre-treated at 300 °C for 3 h to remove the physical adsorbed water and impurity. Then the sample was analyzed at -196 °C to obtain the adsorption and desorption curves. The surface area was calculated by the BET method and the pore size distribution was calculated by the BJH method. The reduction properties of the samples were characterized using Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR, Micromeritics AutoChem 2910). 20 mg sample was filled into a U-type quartz tube and ramped from 50 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate 10 °C/min in 10% H2/Ar at a flow rate 30 mL/min. The signal is detected by TCD during the reduction process. The bulk element contents of the samples were measured by an Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, VISTA-MPX). Before this characterization, all the samples were dissolved in hydrofluoric acid and concentrated nitric acid in a plastic bottle. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) was characterized on a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer with wave number range of 400-2000 cm−1. Among them, 1 mg sample was mixed with 100 mg KBr for characterization. The surface elements content and binding energy of carbides and catalysts were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Perkin Elmer PHI-1600) with Mg-Kα X-ray radiation source (hν = 1253.3 eV). The C 1s peak at 284.6 eV was used as a reference to calibrate the obtained binding energy. The thermal stability and weight loss rate of the samples were characterized by Thermogravimetric analysis (TG, 209 F3 Tarsus). 5 mg sample was placed on the crucible and heated to 800 °C in air (80 mL/min) at the rate of 5 °C /min. 2.5 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis test Catalytic activity of the FexOy@SiO2-x (x = 0, 1, 2 and 3) catalysts were tested in a fixed bed reactor made of a stainless steel (id = 8mm). Prior to test, 0.15 g of catalyst mixed with 1.5 g of quartz was loaded to the reactor, then the catalyst was in-situ reduced. The reduction was carried out by flowing H2 at 60 mL/min, while the temperature was increased from room temperature to 200 °C with ramping rate 2 °C/min, then to 400 °C with ramping rate 1 °C/min and kept at 400 °C for 240 minutes. After the bed temperature was cooled to 50 °C, hydrogen was switched to a mixed gas (H2/CO/Ar = 4.5:4.5:1) at 90 mL/min, and the reaction condition was 300 °C and 2 MPa. The gas products were on-line analyzed using gas chromatograph (Agilent 6820 GC) with a TCD and a FID. The oil and wax products were collected by a cold trap (-6 °C) and a hot trap (170 °C), respectively. The oil and wax products were off-line analyzed using a GC (SP-3420) with a FID. CO conversion (XCO) and C5+ selectivity was calculated by the following formula [23]. Carbon chain growth probability factor (α) was calculated according to Anderson-Schultz-Flory distribution [24]. X CO = moles of inlet CO -moles of outlet CO moles of inlet CO × 100 S CH 4 = moles of C H 4 produced moles of inlet CO − moles of outlet CO − moles of C O 2 produced × 100 S Cx ( x = 2 − 4 ) = moles of C x produced moles of inlet CO - moles of outlet CO- moles of C O 2 produced × 100 S C 5 + = 100 − S CH 4 − S C 2 − S C 3 − S C 4 S CO 2 = moles of CO 2 p r o d u c e d moles of inlet CO - moles of outlet CO × 100 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structure of the catalyst The morphology of the MOF precursor was characterized by SEM, and the result is shown in Fig. 2 . All the four precursors show identical appearance of biconical prism structure, but the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-x (x = 1, 2 and 3) exhibit different morphology from the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-0 after introduction of TEOS. Among them, the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-x has slight morphology change. As shown in Fig. 2c and Fig. 2d, for the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-2 (Fig. 2c) and Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-3 (Fig. 2d) samples, the addition of TEOS caused obvious damage to the morphology of Fe-MIL-88B. This is mainly reflected by the deformation, agglomeration and more fine particles. Comparatively, the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-3 has the most serious deformation and tendency for particle size increase. As seen from Table 1 , the content of silicon in the three samples was variant. The Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-1 contained the most SiO2, while it has nearly same morphology as Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-0 sample. This indicates that the method for preparing Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-1 could introduce the most SiO2 under same condition and cause the least damage to the precursor. To further proving this point, we used Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) to explore the distribution of silicon in the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-x precursor. As shown in Fig. S1, the silicon in the outer layer of the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-1 sample was obviously less than that of both Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-2 and Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-3 samples. In particular, the growth of SiO2 spheres on the outer layer of the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-3 sample could be found. This indicates that the method for Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-1 could achieve fast infiltration of TEOS. N2 adsorption/desorption analysis was used to characterize the structural properties of the sample, and the results are shown in Fig. S2. Usually, the adsorption capacity of the Fe-MIL-88B will increase sharply with pressure rise at low pressure due to the abundant microporous structure of Fe-MIL-88B [25]. After high-temperature carbonization treatment of Fe-MIL-88B, the microporous structure in the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-x precursor will collapse. As shown in Fig. S2, the adsorption capacity didn't increase greatly with pressure rise when the relative pressure is low (p/p0 < 0.02), which indicates that the microporous structure of the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-x collapsed after carbonization while mesoporous structure took the main place. Fig. S2 shows that all samples exhibited a type II adsorption isotherm, and a hysteresis loop appeared between relative pressure from 0.45 to 1.0, indicating mesoporous structure. These mesoporous structures were originated by two factors: One is from carbon removing during calcination process, and the other is due to the accumulation of mesopores through skeleton collapse. Table 1 lists the textural properties from N2 adsorption/desorption analysis for different samples. Apparently, the BET surface area of the sample decreased after calcination due to removal of the carbon layer. The Fe@C@SiO2-1 and FexOy@SiO2-1 had higher BET surface area than the other carbonized and calcined samples, which may be the result of the combined effect of the carbon layer and SiO2. Fig. 3 a and b show the XRD patterns of different samples. As shown in Fig. 3a, the diffraction peaks of the carbonized samples are significantly different. Both Fe@C@SiO2-0 and Fe@C@SiO2-1 show significant diffraction peaks of Fe0 and θ-Fe3C. According to Ma et al. [26], it was deduced that there is a θ-Fe3C shell layer between the junction of the iron species and carbon layer. However, the Fe@C@SiO2-2 and Fe@C@SiO2-3 exhibited the form of iron oxides because the oxygen atoms in the MOF ligand seeped into the iron lattice during carbonization process [16]. For the calcined samples, the XRD results (Fig. 3b) show that except for the FexOy@SiO2-3 sample that has the characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 and slight Fe2O3, the other samples have obvious characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe0, Fe3O4, and Fe2O3. The crystalline size of the active phase was calculated using the Scherrer equation according to peak width of 2θ = 33.2° and 2θ = 35.4° corresponding to Fe2O3 (104) and Fe3O4 (311), and the results are listed in Table 1. After introduction of TEOS, the crystalline size of Fe2O3 in the FexOy@SiO2-x catalyst was decreased. Among them, the FexOy@SiO2-2 catalyst decreased most, having the smallest iron species crystalline size, while the FexOy@SiO2-3 the second and the FexOy@SiO2-1 last. As for the crystalline size of Fe3O4, both FexOy@SiO2-1 and FexOy@SiO2-2 have same size but the FexOy@SiO2-3 has the largest size. This means that the confinement effect of SiO2 in the FexOy@SiO2-3 sample is weak that may be related to its lowest SiO2 content as shown in Table 1. As reported by Li et al. [27], the crystallite size of Fe species decreased with increasing SiO2 content for the Fe/xSiO2 (x = 0, 1, 5, 10, 15, 25) catalysts with different iron loadings by the co-precipitation method. In this study, the SiO2 in the FexOy@SiO2-3 sample did not exhibit a confinement ability and the iron species was increased a lot, which is referred to least SiO2 content. Comparatively, the FexOy@SiO2-1 had a larger SiO2 content and less Fe loading than the FexOy@SiO2-2 sample, while the confinement effect of the former was not as good as that of the FexOy@SiO2-2 sample, which may be related with the fast infiltration of TEOS into Fe-MIL-88B. Another factor may be related to the interaction between the metal and the support that needs to be further explored. Compared with the standard Fe-MIL-88B card in literatures [15], the Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-0 has the most standard diffraction peak (Fig. S3), but these peak intensities gradually weakened with the introduction of TEOS. This shows that the addition of TEOS destroyed the morphology of the Fe-MIL-88B precursor, which is consistent with the SEM results. As shown in Fig. 4 , TEM image of the Fe@C@SiO2-x clearly shows that the iron species were encapsulated in a thick carbon matrix. Li et al. [19] found that even if the pores of Fe-MIL-88B collapse upon being carbonized at high temperature 700 °C, its morphology is still similar with that of the precursor. This indicates that the active iron species of the carbonized sample is tightly wrapped in the carbon matrix. To further understand the structural information of the carbonized sample, the Fe@C@SiO2-0 sample was characterized by High-resolution TEM (HRTEM). As shown in Fig. S4, at the interface between the metal and the carbon layer, it can be clearly observed that the carbonized Fe@C@SiO2-0 sample exhibits a multilayer structure. By measuring the crystalline interplanar spacing, the following species can be distinguished from inside to outside layer: Fe0 (200), θ-Fe3C (200), multilayer graphene (002), and amorphous carbon layers. The finding that the shell containing Fe0 and θ-Fe3C was encapsulated by carbon layer is consistent with the XRD results. Li et al. [28] reported that the ε-Fe2C@graphene catalyst contains large number of defects in multilayer graphene that is conducive to mass transfer and diffusion. Since the graphene layer shown in Fig. S4 is approximately 6-7 layers thick with a relatively regular structure with less defects, which is not conducive to the diffusion of reactants during FTS process. In addition, θ-Fe3C tends to be found in the deactivated catalysts [29,30], it is considered an inactive iron species. Therefore, the sample of the precursor after carbonization does not have good FTS activity. The FexOy@SiO2-x catalysts were obtained after the Fe@C@SiO2-x was calcined in air at 400 °C. To clarify the iron species of the FexOy@SiO2-x catalyst, the morphology and element distribution of the catalyst were characterized by TEM and EDS. Fig. 5 a-d shows that the particle sizes of the four catalysts are significantly different. According to the particle size statistics results (Fig. 5i-l), the iron species size of the four catalysts FexOy@SiO2-x (X = 0, 1, 2 and 3) is 49.8 nm, 28.7 nm, 25.0 nm, and 93.9 nm respectively. This trend is consistent with the results of XRD as listed in Table 1. The difference in the iron species size reflected the different confinement abilities of SiO2, which is also confirmed by the EDS results. Fig. 5e-h shows that FexOy@SiO2-1, FexOy@SiO2-2, and FexOy@SiO2-3 have significant differences in distribution of iron and silicon. Among them, the FexOy@SiO2-2 sample shows the best confinement ability with uniform distribution of Si and Fe. For the FexOy@SiO2-3 catalyst, the poor dispersion of Fe and Si and large particle size are related with the high Fe/Si ratio. Even though the FexOy@SiO2-1 sample has the smallest Fe/Si ratio, the contact between Fe and Si is not as sufficient as in the FexOy@SiO2-2 sample as shown in Fig. S5. The HRTEM of the fresh catalyst FexOy@SiO2-x (Fig. 5m-p) shows that the iron species in the sample are mainly in the form of iron oxide. By observing the edge of the sample, we found that most of the amorphous carbon layer on the outer surface of the sample was removed after calcination at 400 °C with a little graphene layer (1-2 layers) and amorphous carbon layer left. XPS was used to characterize the surface element content of the catalyst, and the results listed in Table 2 also verify this viewpoint. In addition, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve (Fig. S6) shows a weight gain stage and a weight loss stage due to oxidation of iron and carbon removal. There is no obvious difference in the weight gain stage of all catalysts and the weight gain reaches the highest value (102.5 wt.%) at 320 °C. However, as the temperature rise over 320 °C, the weight loss stage is different for different catalysts, which means that the removal amounts of carbon is different for different catalysts. The greater the weight loss, the higher the removal of carbon. Among them, the FexOy@SiO2-0 has the most weight loss (15 wt.%), while the FexOy@SiO2-3 has the least weight loss (5 wt.%) with both FexOy@SiO2-1 and FexOy@SiO2-2 about same as 10 wt.%. 3.2 Metal-support interaction The influencing factors of the metal-support interaction usually include the charge transfer, interfacial perimeter, metal particle morphology, chemical composition, and strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [31]. Among them, the SMSI means that the suboxide support covers the metal particles and minimizes the high surface energy, which requires sufficient contact between the support and the metal particles [32–34]. However, due to the blockage of active sites, this phenomenon is detrimental to the catalytic performance. However, these suboxides can change the (local) electronic structure of the metal surface and act as Lewis acids, thereby promoting the activation of reactants and improving the catalytic performance [35]. SiO2 as a support has been extensively studied [27,36]. The role of SiO2 in FTS catalysts is generally considered to provide large surface area, stabilize small metal crystallites, and enhance the attrition resistance of the catalyst. However, due to the strong interaction between Fe and SiO2, the addition of silica may inhibit the reduction and carburization of iron oxides, and then decrease the FTS activity. Therefore, the effect of interaction between Fe-SiO2 on the FTS performance needs to be carried out. Fig. 6 shows the FT-IR spectra of the sample before and after calcination. Table S1 summarizes the wavenumbers corresponding to the absorption peaks [37,38]. For the FexOy@SiO2-x catalyst with TEOS added, significant Si-O-Si asymmetric stretching vibration peaks at 1075 cm−1 and 1200 cm−1 were observed. Comparatively, the FexOy@SiO2-3 sample has a stronger characteristic absorption peak of SiO2 that is much similar with the peak shape of pure SiO2 (Fig. S7). Among the four samples, the FexOy@SiO2-2 sample has the strongest characteristic peak corresponding to Fe-O-Si, indicating the strongest metal-support interaction since the Fe-O-Si is considered a sign of interaction between Fe species and SiO2 [27]. Compared with the Fe@C@SiO2-x sample before calcination, the characteristic absorption peaks of Fe-O for the four FexOy@SiO2-x catalysts are all significantly enhanced after calcination. In addition, the Si-OH species in the Fe@C@SiO2-1 and Fe@C@SiO2-2 samples were transformed to Fe-O-Si species after calcination. Unlike this, the silicon species in the Fe@C@SiO2-3 sample existed in the form of SiO2 which is another proof for the insufficient contact between Fe and SiO2. Previous studies have shown that a large amounts of hydroxyl groups were formed on the surface of SiO2 after TEOS hydrolysis, which will limit the application of SiO2 [39]. Luo et al. [40] reported that these Si-OH disappeared after TEOS hydrolysis product was calcined at 600 °C. The FT-IR results showed that the asymmetrical stretching vibration peak of Si-OH disappeared and the content of SiO2 increased from 86.72% to 99.92% after calcination. Therefore, we infer that the Si-OH in both Fe@C@SiO2-1 and Fe@C@SiO2-2 samples was transformed to Fe-O-Si during calcination process, confirmed by the emerged peak at 970 cm−1. The Fe-SiO2 interaction can be characterized by the formation of Fe-O-Si between the iron species and SiO2. These species exist in the carbonized sample and is increased after calcination which in turn inhibits the agglomeration of Fe particles and keeps the high dispersion of iron species on these MOF-derived catalysts [41]. To further explore the interaction between iron species and silica, we used XPS to study the electronic structure of Fe and Si in the catalyst. Fig. 7 a and Table 2 shows the XPS fitting curves and peak position information of Fe 2p for the catalysts. For the fresh FexOy@SiO2-x catalysts, the XPS spectra of Fe species can be dissolved to 8 peaks. The binding energy of Fe 2p3 [42] around 709.5 eV and 711.0 eV are fitted to the peaks of Fe (II) and Fe (III), respectively. This indicates that the Fe species on the surface of the fresh catalyst are present in the form of Fe (II) and Fe (III). The specific peak fitting information is listed in Table 2. Apparently, the binding energies of Fe (II) and Fe (III) was shifted to higher binding energy after introducing TEOS. The binding energies of Fe on the FexOy@SiO2-1, FexOy@SiO2-2, and FexOy@SiO2-3 increased by 0.4, 0.6, and 0.2 eV, respectively due to metal-support interaction. In addition, electron transfer can also be found from the XPS spectra of Si 2p (Fig. 7b). Compared with the standard binding energy of Si 2p (103.5 eV) in SiO2 [27], the binding energy of SiO2 shifts to lower value due to the presence of surrounding iron species in the fresh catalyst. Among the samples, FexOy@SiO2-2 has the largest binding energy shift. The binding energy shift shows the change in the electronic structure of the corresponding element in the sample [43]. From this viewpoint, there is electron transfer between Fe and Si atoms, and the catalyst exhibits an electron-deficient state of Fe species. Since the FexOy@SiO2-2 catalyst has the largest energy shift, infers that it has the strongest interaction between Fe and SiO2 support. The H2-TPR curve shows the reduction behavior of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8 , there are two peaks for the FexOy@SiO2-0 and three peaks for the other catalysts. The reduction peak around 300 °C is attributed to the reduction from Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 [27,44,45], while the reduction peak ranging 450-750 °C is considered the reduction from Fe3O4 or FexO to Fe. Except these two peaks shown in the FexOy@SiO2-0 sample, the third reduction peak at temperature over 600 °C was found on the other catalysts. This is attributed to the interaction of Fe species and SiO2, which makes the reduction of Fe species more difficult. In addition, the second reduction peak became weak while the third peak became strong for the FexOy@SiO2-x with x from 1 to 3. The second peak on the FexOy@SiO2-1 is nearly same as that on the FexOy@SiO2-0. While for both FexOy@SiO2-2 and FexOy@SiO2-3 catalysts, the second peak decreased a lot while the third peak increased, which depicts the combined effect of particle size and metal-support interaction. 4 FTS performance and structure-activity relationship 4.1 Activity To study the FTS performance of the catalyst and the effect of introduction SiO2 on the iron-based catalyst for FTS, FTS tests was carried out. CO conversion variation with time under the same reaction conditions is shown in Fig. 9 a. It could be seen that the activation time for the four catalysts is significantly different even though the CO conversion increased with time first and then reached a stable value. Comparatively, the FexOy@SiO2-0 and FexOy@SiO2-3 catalysts have shorter induction time than the others. After 42 - 62 h, the reaction on FexOy@SiO2-0 and FexOy@SiO2-3 becomes stable with the CO conversion being 24% and 49% respectively. However, the activation time of the FexOy@SiO2-1 and FexOy@SiO2-2 catalyst is much longer while the CO conversion significantly improved to 71% and 88.7% respectively after reaction for 120 h. To understand the variation of active phase, XRD analysis of the used catalysts was done (Fig. 9b). Compared with the fresh catalysts (Fig. 3b), a phase transition from iron oxide to χ-Fe5C2 after reaction occurred, and χ-Fe5C2 is generally considered one of the main active phases of the Fe-based FTS catalyst [46]. Compared with the reported Fe-based catalysts, the FTS activity on the FexOy@SiO2-2 catalyst is pretty high, as listed in Table 3 . Li et al. [28] synthesized an iron carbide nanocomposite by pyrolyzing a molten mixture of glucose, urea and Fe(NO3)3⋅9H2O under 300 °C and syngas (H2/CO=1), the FTY value reaches 5.83 × 10−4 molCO/(gFe⋅s) while the carbonization yields the catalyst with ε-Fe2C as the active phase. There are also reports that the activity of ε-Fe2C nanoparticles is 4.3 times that of χ-Fe5C2, which is even comparable to the FTS activity of metallic Ru [47]. In this work, the FTY value of the FexOy@SiO2-2 catalyst reaches 4.54 × 10−4 molCO/(gFe⋅s) (Table 3), which is close to that of the catalyst with ε-Fe2C as the active phase at the same reaction temperature. It was reported [27] that the Fe-SiO2 catalyst prepared by co-precipitation method has a maximum FTS activity as 0.072 × 10−4 molCO/(gFe⋅s) when the Fe/Si ratio is 15. Comparatively, the FeOx/SiO2 catalyst obtained by Fe-MOF material has much higher FTS activity as 4.5 × 10−4 molCO/(gFe⋅s). 4.2 Selectivity The selectivities of different catalysts are shown in Fig. S8. There is a slight variation for selectivity with time. After the reaction becomes stable, the detailed hydrocarbon distribution is summarized in Table 3. It could be seen that C5+ selectivities were 84.97%, 73.72%, 70.58% and 79.15% for FexOy@SiO2-0, FexOy@SiO2-1, FexOy@SiO2-2 and FexOy@SiO2-3 catalyst respectively, while CH4 selectivity ranged from 5% to 10%. These selectivity results show that the carbon chain growth ability of the catalyst gradually decreases as the reaction progresses. The chain growth factor α of the catalysts is calculated upon reaction stabilization and is listed in Table 3. Among the catalysts, the FexOy@SiO2-2 catalyst has the highest C5-C11 selectivity and C2-C4 selectivity. Especially, its selectivity for C5-C11 reaches the maximum limit according to the ASF distribution. By observing the trends of the catalyst reaction activity and selectivity, we can clearly find that there is a significant relationship between the catalyst conversion and selectivity. As the conversion increases with reaction time, the selectivity of C5+ decreased while the selectivity of CH4 increased. Burtron H. Davis et al [48]. reported that water-gas shift (WGS) reaction becomes more intense at Fe-based catalysts with higher CO conversion. The WGS reaction will increase the H2/CO ratio on the catalyst surface, thereby enhancing the chain termination ability of affecting on product selectivity. Fig. S9 shows the trend of the CO2 selectivity with TOS. Apparently, WGS activity increases with CO conversion increase, as indicated by the increased CO2 selectivity. 4.3 Structure-activity relationship The TEM images of the used catalysts are shown in Fig. 9c-f. We can clearly find that the FexOy@SiO2-0 catalyst has no obvious core-shell structure, but the other FexOy@SiO2-x catalysts have carbide shell layer on the outer surface of the metal particles, which indicates that the iron species were further carburized during the reaction. The HRTEM results shows that the FexOy@SiO2-2 (Fig. 10 ) catalyst has an obvious core-shell structure with a χ-Fe5C2 shell coated on the metal particles surface. For the iron-based FTS catalysts, there is a positive correlation between the growth of iron carbide and reaction time [15]. The formation and growth process of χ-Fe5C2 is the activation to produce active sites, which makes the catalyst more active in FTS. χ-Fe5C2 is the main active phase of FTS and its content is related to the activity. The XRD characterization of the used FexOy@SiO2-0 catalyst (Fig. 9b) also indicated that the diffraction peak of χ-Fe5C2 is the weakest, corresponding to its low activity for FTS. Fig. 9g-j shows the particle size distribution of the used catalyst. Compared with the TEM result of the catalyst before reaction (Fig. 5), the metal particle size of the used catalyst is greatly decreased that makes more active metal surfaces exposed to reactants. This process occurs with the carburizing process, which leads to an increase of active sites. This is attributed to the poor interaction between metal-support interaction, poor mechanical stability of big particles and density difference between iron oxide and iron carbide phases [10]. On traditional SiO2 supported Fe catalysts, the strong interaction between Fe and SiO2 will decrease the reduction degree FTS performance. The SMSI on the traditional SiO2 supported Fe catalysts is due to the close contact Fe species and SiO2 support. However, the contact between the Fe species and the support in this paper is not so close due to the existence of carbon layer between Fe species and SiO2 support. The removal of carbon layer left some spaces between Fe species and SiO2 which weaken the interaction between Fe and SiO2. Due to the anchoring effect of SiO2 on the Fe species, the reduction degree was not decreased by the increase of SMSI on this kind of catalyst. Furthermore, the activity of the catalyst is greatly improved by exposing more active metal surface to the reactants. 5 Conclusions TEOS was introduced into the framework of Fe-MIL-88B during its preparation process. With the confinement effect, TEOS was uniformly dispersed in Fe-MIL-88B. Three kinds of Fe-MIL-88B@SiO2-x precursors were prepared by introducing TEOS in different stages during preparation of Fe-MIL-88B, which was transformed to FexOy@SiO2-x after carbonization and calcination. The introduction of TEOS effectively prevents the agglomeration of iron species during calcination process, exhibiting a good confinement effect on iron species. Among them, the FexOy@SiO2-2 catalyst has the highest CO conversion as 89%, FTY as 4.54 × 10−4 molCO/(gFe⋅s) and gasoline selectivity which is attributed to the smallest iron oxides size and the form of χ-Fe5C2 layers that greatly improve the active sites and diffusion of the molecules. In addition, another factor is the Fe-SiO2 interaction that has obvious influence on the chemical/structural characteristics of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Metal Organic Frameworks makes it being used as a template to prepare highly dispersed catalysts. The Fe@C catalyst prepared by pyrolysis of Fe-MOF precursor, depicts a core-shell structure with carbon layers being coated on the outer surface of iron species. Since the diffusion of molecules through carbon layers is suppressed, the active iron sites in the interior could not be fully utilized. Based on this realization, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the silicon source was introduced the MOF during the preparation process of Fe-MOF. After carbonization and calcination, the carbon layer was removed while the iron species were confined by the SiO2 yielding the FexOy@SiO2 catalyst. The confinement effect of SiO2 greatly prevented the agglomeration of iron species during calcination process. Compared with Fe@C catalyst without silicon source, the prepared FexOy@SiO2 catalyst resulted in an enhanced FTS activity with FTY as 4.54 × 10−4 molCO/(gFe⋅s) and gasoline fraction selectivity. Upon using same quantity of TEOS, the dispersion degree of iron species and the confinement effect of SiO2 could be regulated by just changing the introduction order of TEOS, corresponding different FTS performances. The FexOy-SiO2 interaction in the catalyst and its influence on the properties of the FexOy@SiO2 catalyst are discussed and structure-activity relationship was explored.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active FexOy@SiO2 catalyst for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis through the confinement effect of metal organic frameworks material: Preparation and structure-activity relationship
